Idiom (Ladin): Al n’è mia bel de dagn sü la lenëia cun la lua
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause with prepositional phrase; negation with 'n’è mia'
Figurative Meaning: It’s pointless to try something impossible or absurd.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to chopping wood with the moon—an ironic take on futility common in Val Badia folklore.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Ladin): [al nɛ ʔmia bɛl de dan su la leˈnei̯a kun la lua]
First Example Sentence: Te voi dascë la man, ma al n’è mia bel de dagn sü la lenëia cun la lua.
Second Example Sentence: Al prova de convëncerla, ma é al sté n bel de dagn sü la lenëia cun la lua.
Third Example Sentence: N paes cun n cëuf tancà al é bel de dagn sü la lenëia cun la lua.

Idiom (Ladin): Vëgnì fora coma n pom dala nìva
Figurative Meaning: To suddenly appear or be unexpectedly revealed.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Apples kept in snow were preserved for winter in alpine villages.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Ladin): [veɲˈi fora ˈkoma n ˈpom ˈdala ˈniːva]
First Example Sentence: Tl moment pì stranc, é vëgnù fora coma n pom dala nìva.
Second Example Sentence: N idea bela al é vëgnuda fora coma n pom dala nìva.
Third Example Sentence: Al se presentè fora dl nient, coma n pom dala nìva.

Figurative Meaning: A very clumsy or awkward person.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Bears are admired and mocked in Ladin legend for both strength and clumsiness.
First Example Sentence: Më cugnà al é che pestor de ors!
Second Example Sentence: N’ha sbrocà dutc i plats, che pestor de ors.
Third Example Sentence: Al va da per tüc sönc, che pestor de ors!

Figurative Meaning: To stay proud or keep one’s dignity.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to posture, but linked to pride and dignity in battle and hardship.
First Example Sentence: Anche che j é masa, tgn la cresta ota.
Second Example Sentence: L’é sté da coraj, tgnì la cresta ota.
Third Example Sentence: Par n Ladin, l’é impurtant de tgnì la cresta ota.

Figurative Meaning: Tension is rising; trouble is coming.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in mountain life where weather changes rapidly; used figuratively in many valleys.
First Example Sentence: Tira l’aria da timpesta cun j che s barufa.
Second Example Sentence: Tira l’aria da timpesta da chësta sera.
Third Example Sentence: L’é mej de resté a chësa, tira l’aria da timpesta.

Idiom (Ladin): Mo l'é na bala dla grossa
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: The word 'bala' refers to a ball or falsehood, commonly used in disputes.
First Example Sentence: Mo l'é na bala dla grossa che l’à fat chel lavur.
Second Example Sentence: Dësc de n’auta, mo l’é na bala dla grossa!
Third Example Sentence: Tütc i save chësta l’é na bala dla grossa.

Figurative Meaning: To stay alert or be cautious.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in farming and mountain safety practices.
First Example Sentence: Sté cun l’öi sot che i é masa ròbes a vëdé.
Second Example Sentence: Të va da par to cont, sté cun l’öi sot.
Third Example Sentence: Sté cun l’öi sot, che n se save mai.

Idiom (Ladin): J é coma n purcel te la frëida
Figurative Meaning: He/she is totally out of place or uncomfortable.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Pigs were rarely let outside in snow—used mockingly for awkwardness.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Ladin): [j‿e ˈkoma n purˈtʃel te la ˈfrøi̯da]
First Example Sentence: J é coma n purcel te la frëida tl reunion.
Second Example Sentence: Al se sentiva coma n purcel te la frëida.
Third Example Sentence: J é vegnù cun n vestì sbalié, coma n purcel te la frëida.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Infinitive clause with definite article and noun
Figurative Meaning: To end up badly or foolishly.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Donkeys used to be mocked for missteps and bad endings.
First Example Sentence: J à fat tüta chësta fatica e l’à fé la fin dl mus.
Second Example Sentence: Sta atent, che ti fé la fin dl mus.
Third Example Sentence: Chel projet l’é finì mal, fé la fin dl mus.

Idiom (Ladin): Ëi l dial da la mont
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Verb + definite noun phrase; archaic structure
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional image of mountains echoing secrets and rumors.
First Example Sentence: Të senté che j à ëi l dial da la mont su de lü?
Second Example Sentence: N se à da fé l dial da la mont su nissun.
Third Example Sentence: L’é jënt che ëi semper l dial da la mont.
